description: Thousands of parents have been left in the dark as uncertainty continues to surround this summer's Kellogg's Cúl Camps due to the Covid-19 restrictions.
text:
Thousands of parents have been left in the dark as uncertainty continues to
surround this summer's Kellogg's Cul Camps due to the Covid-19 restrictions.As
recently as last week, the website was continuing to take bookings for the
week-long sports camps.The says it is "hopeful" they will still go ahead in
some kind of format.The popular events which cater to children aged between
six and 13 had more than 36,000 registrations in Leinster alone last year.At
the time of booking last week, parents were advised that all Government
guidelines would be followed, and if the camps could not go ahead, full
refunds would be issued.However, this week the website's booking system was
shut down entirely, with the issuing a statement on its position."We are
currently reconfiguring our camps schedule due to the current Covid-19
pandemic," it read."Unfortunately, we are unable to accept online bookings at
this time. Once this process is complete, our website will be open for
registration. Thank you for your patience and understanding during this
unprecedented time." director of communications Alan Milton said: "We hope to
publish our return to safe activity doc in the next week at which stage there
may be more clarity around the Cul Camps."Another source said the did not
expect camps booked in July to go ahead at this point.However, it is hoped
that some events will be run in August, provided the clubs in question can
allow for social distancing."It depends on the size of the club and what kind
of facilities they have, if they have large outdoor areas or not," the source
said."If a club has normally 200 children in one group, they might only be
able to accept 80 for the summer camps."While schools and colleges will remain
closed until September, some summer camps have been deemed safer due to the
fact they are held outdoors, which lessens the spread of coronavirus.National
Cul Camps co-ordinator Charlie Harrison is finalising a roadmap for how these
camps can take place nationwide, HSE guidelines permitting.Earlier this week,
it appeared the Cul Camps would be able to take place this summer, but all
activities will have to be carried out with strict safeguards.Dr Tony Holohan,
the chief medical officer, said: "Government is going to consider and accept
them before they become part of any easing of restrictions." Independent

title: Thousands of parents in dark over plans for GAA camps [Irish Independent (Ireland)]
html: Thousands of parents have been left in the dark as uncertainty continues to surround this summer's Kellogg's Cúl Camps due to the Covid-19 restrictions.As recently as last week, the website was continuing to take bookings for the week-long sports camps.The says it is "hopeful" they will still go ahead in some kind of format.The popular events which cater to children aged between six and 13 had more than 36,000 registrations in Leinster alone last year.At the time of booking last week, parents were advised that all Government guidelines would be followed, and if the camps could not go ahead, full refunds would be issued.However, this week the website's booking system was shut down entirely, with the issuing a statement on its position."We are currently reconfiguring our camps schedule due to the current Covid-19 pandemic," it read."Unfortunately, we are unable to accept online bookings at this time. Once this process is complete, our website will be open for registration. Thank you for your patience and understanding during this unprecedented time." director of communications Alan Milton said: "We hope to publish our return to safe activity doc in the next week at which stage there may be more clarity around the Cúl Camps."Another source said the did not expect camps booked in July to go ahead at this point.However, it is hoped that some events will be run in August, provided the clubs in question can allow for social distancing."It depends on the size of the club and what kind of facilities they have, if they have large outdoor areas or not," the source said."If a club has normally 200 children in one group, they might only be able to accept 80 for the summer camps."While schools and colleges will remain closed until September, some summer camps have been deemed safer due to the fact they are held outdoors, which lessens the spread of coronavirus.National Cúl Camps co-ordinator Charlie Harrison is finalising a roadmap for how these camps can take place nationwide, HSE guidelines permitting.Earlier this week, it appeared the Cúl Camps would be able to take place this summer, but all activities will have to be carried out with strict safeguards.Dr Tony Holohan, the chief medical officer, said: "Government is going to consider and accept them before they become part of any easing of restrictions." Independent
